record.inscrip: Omnium Pontificum a S. Petro usque ad presentem effigies
record.note: The original plate contains 237 portraits terminating with the pontificate of Sixtus V (1585-1590). Two new sets of portraits were added at a later date. The first, including portraits of Urban VIII and Gregory XIV, was published at Rome by the heirs of Claudio Duchetti, ca. 1590-1591 (Cf. Hu 135b); the second, including the portraits of Innocent IX and Clement VIII, was published between 1592 and 1605 (Cf. Hu 135c and d).

record.note: L-A v.2, p.327 lists a set of 63 portraits of French kings engraved in 1600 by Jean Leclerc after Leonard Gaultier which could be closely related to our plates. For other 16th century engravings of this subject cf. the index of L-A v.2, p.437 s.v. Rois de France, portraits.

record.note:
Page 9 on upper right. The engraving probably comes from a Dutch edition of Panvinio's De ludis circensibus
published in the 17th century. Though the plate states aeneis formeis expressa Onuphrii Panvini
, it is difficult to ascertain the degree of his contribution to the engraving. The listings concerning him as engraver in NaKL v.12, p.276 and Ben v.6, p.507 are unreliable, and he is not listed in T-B. For bio-bibliographical information on Panvinio cf. EI v.26, p.219 and Zedler, v.26, cols. 602-605.

record.note: No.29 on lower right. Meyer v.2, p.495, n.24 lists an engraving by Azelt of Villa Pamphili bearing the number 32 on the upper right.

record.inscrip: Roma Victrix de Dacia Provincia subacta triumphans. Vultu Achabitu barbarorumque spolis inlustris
Triclinarium lectorem tripedis mensae et accumbentium ex marmoreis tabulis graphica deformatio

record.subj: Statues Of The Dioscuri At The Quirinal Back View
record.inscrip: Equitum, in Quirinali, aversa parte, marmorei colossi... Praxitelis et Fidiae manu
Io non son (come paio) un Babbuino...Chi terra me' che no'1 ridica poi
record.note: The inscription is a sonetto caudato. Pas v.6, p.120, n.118, attributes this engraving to Nicolas Beatrizet.

record.inscrip: Commodi imp. faciem atque habitum Herculis induti...statua insignis ita ut in Belvedere...extat

Sic Romae ex Marmore sculp. in Palatio Pont. qui vulgo dicitur Belvedere

record.inscrip: [Praecipua Urbis Romanae Templa]
record.ref: BM v.200, col.223 s.v. Regnartius and v.207, col.629 s.v. Rossi
record.note: Regnard's name appears in the dedication on engraving n.3 (B 192). His designs of Roman churches were first published in Varie bella inventioni de tempio ... (Paris Michel Vanlochom 1631); a more complete edition, containing 32 plates, was published as Praecipua urbis Romanae templa (Rome, 1650); finally, they were also included in Insignium Romae templorum prospectus exteriores interioresque ... ([Rome] Io. Iacobo de Rubeis 1684), containing 72 numbered plates. A comparison between the engravings listed here and those in the de Rossi edition (as listed in A-B), shows marked variants both in the text of the inscriptions and in the measurements.
record.inscrip: Facies externa Templi Sancta Mariae Transpontem Sancti Angeli Ordinis Carmelitarum
record.note: (Engraving n.1)

Praecipua aliquot Romanae antiquitatis ruinarum monimenta, vivis prospectibus, ad veri imitationem affabre designata
record.note: The complete set consists of 24 numbered and lettered engravings plus an engraved title page. In the set recorded here, engraving B 225 is a duplicate of B 224. This same set apparently was also executed by Jacques Androuet du Cerceau in 1560 (cf. L-A v.1, p.53f.) and by Battista Pittoni, published at Venice in 1561 (cf. NaKL v.13, p.9).

record.inscrip: Praecipua aliquot Romanae antiquitatis ruinarum monimenta, vivis prospectibus, ad veri imitationem affabre designata
record.note: The complete set consists of 24 numbered and lettered engravings plus an engraved title page. In the set recorded here, engraving B 225 is a duplicate of B 224. This same set apparently was also executed by Jacques Androuet du Cerceau in 1560 (cf. L-A v.1, p.53f.) and by Battista Pittoni, published at Venice in 1561 (cf. NaKL v.13, p.9).

record.inscrip: [Praecipua aliquot Romanae antiquitatis ruinarum monimenta?]
record.note:
These engravings apparently belong to a new and enlarged edition of the Praecipua
(cf. engravings B 210 to B 235); this, however, seems to be a different edition than the one which, according to Hol v.4, p.183, was the second, edited by Carel Allaert, and published towards the end of the seventeenth century, with 59 plates. It should be noted here that, according to Brunet, v.2, col.114, there was a 1551 edition of the Praecipua
which contained 37 plates plus the title page. Variations in details, especially in the representation of human figures, differentiates these five plates from those of the 1551 edition listed above. Cf. also engravings B 241 to B 247 and C 582 and C 583.

record.inscrip: [I vestigi dell'antichita di Roma]
record.note: Part of a numbered set of 40 engravings; missing are the title page and engraving n.40. The portrait of Jacob Schletzer, to whom this particular edition was dedicated, appears on engraving n.2 of the set (B 248).
record.inscrip: Vestigii della Isola di Sto. Bartholomeo, gia anticamente detta L'isola di Giove Licaonio... Hora il chiamono di Sto. Bartholomeo per esser la chiesa di questo santo posta in detta isola
record.note: (Engraving n.39)

record.inscrip: Descriptio urbis Romae quadratae et postea ab oriens regibus aliisque successu temporis amplificatae
Novissima urbis Romae descriptio
record.ref: Frutaz, v.1, p.197 and v.2, pianta 138, tav.278

record.inscrip: Der Stadt Rom boden und circkel sampt thor und porten wie sie gestanden ist vor zeiten do sie noch in ihrer herrlichkeit was
record.ref: Frutaz, v.1, p.58f and v.2, pianta 14, tav.23

record.inscrip: La figure de la place, ou fut iadiz la cite de Rome, avec ses portes, quand elle estoit en sa grand'fleur
record.ref: Brunet, v.3, col.1945 s.v. Munster. (Cf. also the references to engraving B 288)
record.note:
This is the same woodcut as the one listed above. It was removed from the 1575 edition of the French translation of Munster's Cosmographia
, where it appeared on columns 547-548; in the earlier edition of the French translation (Basel, 1552), according to A-B p.7, n.62, this map appeared on p.154.

record.inscrip: Iulius III. Pont. Opt. Max
Marcellus .II. Pont. Opt. Max
Nicolao Ardinghello Cardinalis annum agens XLIIII maiorum memoriae nepotumque imitationi

record.subj: Military Insignia And Instruments Of War From A Marble Tablet
record.inscrip: In aedib....Card. de Caesis...tabula marm. cohortium signis duobus, aquilaque legionaria atque aliis cum instrumentis bellicis tum cavea pullaria inscriptionibusque perelegantibus insignis

record.subj: Relic Of The Inscription Of Christ'S Cross
record.inscrip: Imago triumphalis tituli vivifuae Crucis D.N. Jesu Christi qualis hodie Romae apud Cartusianos intra Basilicam S. Crucis in Ierusalem...conspicitur...
record.note:
The story of the discovery of this relic is told in Duret, Histoire
, p.799: "R. Volaterran livr. 22. Anthropolog. escrit que du temps du Pape Innocent VIII. en l'an 1492 le titre de la Croix de nostre Seignr. Iesus Christ fut trouve en la Basilique de S. Croix au milieu du temple, cache dans une muraille escrit aux 3. langues susdictes Hebraique, Grecque & Latine en ces mots seuls: Iesus Nazarenus Re.
Le reste des mots, estant rongez, ou effacez." For the reference to Volaterranus see his Comm.
, fol.3166.

record.subj: Martyrdom Scenes Of Four Female Saints
record.note: The plate contains 4 separate engravings, each measuring 7 x 12 cm., representing the martyrdom of the following saints: S. Plautilla, S. Agata, S. Bonosa and S. Theodora.

record.inscrip: Quanto honorato sei benigno bacco:/.../ festegia ognun dele tue fronde adorno
record.engrv: Master B with the Die (monogram) after [Giulio Romano]
record.note:
The inscription is an ottava
.

record.inscrip: Orata
record.note:
The plate is numbered P 62. It comes from Ippolito Salviani's Aquatilium animalium historiae
, published at Rome in 1558(?) (the frontispiece is dated 1554); the 90 plates of this book were published separately by Antonio Lafreri. The name of the fish is also given in Greek and in Latin.
There are 5 cartouches on this plate which is lettered T.

record.inscrip: Mentr'el tuo Padre in quella, in questa parte/ ... /che gia tenesti'l mondo sotto'l piede
record.engrv: Master B with the Die after [Giulio Romano]

record.inscrip: Uccide Phebo il gran Phiton. Serpente/ ... /Tal che per Daphne poi si strugge e muore/
record.engrv: Master B with the Die after [Giulio Romano]
record.note:
This is the first in a series of four engravings describing the story of Daphne and Apollo. The inscription is an ottava.
.

record.subj: Mercury Handing A Reed Pipe To Minerva

record.note: Cf. Hu p.137f. for dating of van Aelst's activity as publisher.

record.engrv: Marco Dente da Ravenna (monogram) after [Marcantonio Raimondi]
record.note: The address of the former publisher Antonio Salamanca has been erased from this engraving.

record.inscrip: Sumptum ex fragmentis antiquitatum Romae
record.engrv: Master B with the Die after [Raphael?]
record.note: The companion plate (cf. Hu 78a; Qu 247; Pe p.16, n.924) is no included in this collection. (For a later impression of the same cf. B 306.).

record.subj: Scenes From The Campaign Of Scipio Africanus Against Syphax Of Numidia
record.engrv: Master B with the Die after Raphael
record.inscrip: Vittoria havuta da Scipione contro Siface Re de Numidia ...per la qualvittoria torno in Roma trionfante

record.subj: Scenes From The Campaign Of Scipio Africanus Against Syphax Of Numidia
record.engrv: Master B with the Die after Raphael
record.inscrip: Trionfo di Scipione tornando vittorioso d'Africa, contro Siface Re di Numidia ...

record.subj: Two Muses And Zodiacal Signs Of Libra And Scorpio

record.note: Left margin damaged.

record.subj: Hercules, Bacchus, And And A Fourth Male Figure
record.engrv: Giorgio Ghisi (monogram) after Francesco Primaticcio da Bologna
record.note: This is the first of a series of four engravings of mythological deities after oval ceiling frescoes by Primaticcio.

record.subj: The Injured Scipio Returning From The Battleffeld
record.ref: Praun, p.146, n.260 (engraving by Leon Daven dated 1540)

record.subj: The Virgin Of The Seven Sorrows
record.inscrip: Non doluere meo mihi fixa in pectore tela,/Tela dolent, nato quae doluere meo

record.subj: The Holy Family And St. John The Baptist
record.inscrip: Ecce ag[nus] Dei
record.note: The signature of Raffaelino da Reggio appeared in some engravings at the left hand corner. In our engraving it was replaced by another name (perhaps that of Calisto Ferranti) which afterwards was also erased.

record.subj: The Fable Of Cupid And Psyche
record.engrv: [Master B with the Die and Agostino Veneziano after Raphael or Michiel Coxie]
record.note:
Part of a set of 32 numbered engravings. Those missing, with the exception of numbers 7 and 9 of the set, can be found in the [Raphael] volume listed above. Twenty-nine of these engravings were executed by Master B with the Die, though his monogram only appears on numbers 6 and 9; the remaining three, numbers 4, 7, and 13, bear the monogram of Agostino Veneziano. Most of the engravings listed here bear the signature of the publisher Antonio Salamanca; they probably belong to the category of those engravings which were retouched by Francesco Villamena (cf. Ba v.15, p.212); numbers 2, 5, 12, and 15 of the set were left unsigned by the publisher. The inscription of each engraving consists of an Ottava
composed by an unknown poet probably before 1550, not mentioned in Ugo de Maria's study of the fable (cf. La favola de Cupido e Psiche nella letteratura e nell' arte italiana
, [Bologna, 1899], p.79f.). Numbers 2 and 5 of this set lack the ottave
altogether and apparently belong to an earlier stage (cf. Ba v.15, p.212 and Vienna, p.54). This set was also engraved by Jacques Androuet du Cerceau (cf. L-A v.l, p.39f., n.1-32).
record.inscrip: [Venus points out Psyche to Cupid]
record.note: ([Engraving n.2])This print is the reverse of the one described by Ba v.15, p.213, n.40.

composed by an unknown poet probably before 1550, not mentioned in Ugo de Maria's study of the fable (cf. La favola de Cupido e Psiche nella letteratura e nell' arte italiana
, [Bologna, 1899], p.79f.). Numbers 2 and 5 of this set lack the ottave
altogether and apparently belong to an earlier stage (cf. Ba v.15, p.212 and Vienna, p.54). This set was also engraved by Jacques Androuet du Cerceau (cf. L-A v.l, p.39f., n.1-32).
record.inscrip: Dalle una bossola hor, che al negro inpero/ ... /Con quanto debbia fare, onde camina
record.note: (Engraving n.24)

record.subj: The Fable Of Cupid And Psyche
record.engrv: [Master B with the Die and Agostino Veneziano after Raphael or Michiel Coxie]
record.note:
Part of a set of 32 numbered engravings. Those missing, with the exception of numbers 7 and 9 of the set, can be found in the [Raphael] volume listed above. Twenty-nine of these engravings were executed by Master B with the Die, though his monogram only appears on numbers 6 and 9; the remaining three, numbers 4, 7, and 13, bear the monogram of Agostino Veneziano. Most of the engravings listed here bear the signature of the publisher Antonio Salamanca; they probably belong to the category of those engravings which were retouched by Francesco Villamena (cf. Ba v.15, p.212); numbers 2, 5, 12, and 15 of the set were left unsigned by the publisher. The inscription of each engraving consists of an Ottava
composed by an unknown poet probably before 1550, not mentioned in Ugo de Maria's study of the fable (cf. La favola de Cupido e Psiche nella letteratura e nell' arte italiana
, [Bologna, 1899], p.79f.). Numbers 2 and 5 of this set lack the ottave
altogether and apparently belong to an earlier stage (cf. Ba v.15, p.212 and Vienna, p.54). This set was also engraved by Jacques Androuet du Cerceau (cf. L-A v.l, p.39f., n.1-32).

record.inscrip: [Amplissimi...triumphi...ex antiquissimis...monumentis accuratissima descriptio]
record.engrv: [Gerard de Jode? after Maarten van Heemskerk or Onofrio Panvinio]
record.note: The set consists of an engraved title page (missing in this collection) and eleven numbered engravings. It comes from the Veterum Rom. Ornatissimi...triumphi ... which was first published at Amsterdam [1560] (cf. BM v.179, col.461); it was later published at Amsterdam in 1598; at Rome in 1618 (cf. Brunet v.4, col.350), and at Rome by Gio. Giacomo de Rossi (cf. Frutaz, v.l, P.67f. and v.2, pianta n.22, n.9-12, tav.46-49). The inscriptions in this set constitute one continuous text. For a discussion on Panvinio's activity as engraver cf. the note to engraving A 52; a related engraving is catalogued under D 993.
record.inscrip: Triumphi maioris, i[n urbe Romana ob victoriam celebrati typus]
record.note: ([Engraving n.1])
This engraving is badly mutilated (approximately one fourth of the original has been preserved).

[Li cinque ordini con le loro regole et ornamenti cavati dall'antico]
record.engrv: ([Jerome David or Camillo Cungi)]? after Giovanni Battista Montano]
record.ref:
Montano, Archit.
(1636), lib.1, pl.[41 and 42] and Montano, Archit.
(1691), lib.1, pl.41 and 42
record.note:
These two engravings appear at the end of Gio. Battista Montano's Archit.
where they follow a numbered plate bearing number 40 at the upper right corner. Apparently they were not included in the first edition published in 1624 which contains 40 plates only. They already appear in the 1636 edition (BM and Brunet list only 40 plates for this edition). In the Ferrante edition, engraving B 354 bears a number two at the lower right while B 355 bears there a number 4; both engravings are unnumbered at the upper right. In the 1691 edition, B 354 bears a number 42 at the upper right; B 355, a number 41; at the lower right they bear the same numbering as the 1636 edition. For other plates of Montano's libro primo
see engravings C 441 to C 469.
record.inscrip: [Three caryatides]
record.note: (Engraving n.[41];number 2 at lower right)

Libro primo
at head of engraving.

record.inscrip: [Raccolta de tempii e sepolchri disegnati dall'antico]
record.engrv: [(Jerome David or Camillo Cungi)? after Giovanni Battista Montano]
record.ref: NaKL v.3, p.434 s.v. David and v.10, p.487 s.v. Montano
record.note:
These two plates come from what came to be known as the third book of Montano's Archit.
This book was published separately, apparently for the first time, in 1638, two years after Calisto Ferrante's edition of Montano's Archit.
in four books. Unfortunately neither BM nor BN indicate how many plates the 1638 edition contains. NaKL's entry refers to a 1708 edition of 42 plates which seems to include material from books two through five of the Archit.
For another plate from Montano's third book see engraving C 473.
record.inscrip: [Sepolcro di porfido nel Tempio detto di Bacco...]
record.note: (Engraving n.[46])

in four books. Unfortunately neither BM nor BN indicate how many plates the 1638 edition contains. NaKL's entry refers to a 1708 edition of 42 plates which seems to include material from books two through five of the Archit.

record.subj: Friezes And Bas-Reliefs Of Roman Antiquity
record.inscrip: [Admiranda Romanarum antiquitatum ac veteris sculpturae vestigia anaglyphico opere elaborata ex marmoreis exemplaribus quae Romae adhuc extant...]
record.engrv: Pietro Santi Bartoli in part after [Francois Perrier]
record.ref: BM v.213, col.2 s.v. Santi Bartoli
record.note:
Part of a set of 83 numbered plates including the title page and the dedicatory page (BN lists 84 plates) published for the first time in 1685(?) by Gio. Giacomo de Rossi, and then again in 1693 by Domenico de Rossi. Bartoli apparently re-engraved and enlarged Francois Perrier's Icones et segmenta illustrium e marmore tabularum
first published at Rome (and/or Paris?) in 1645 (or 1650?) containing 53 plates (cf. BM v.187, col.194 and BN v.133, col.1018). Engravings 53 and 54 of the 1693 edition (this last one, B 372 in our collection) still bear Perrier's monogram.
record.inscrip: [Ara, seu basis quadrata lateribus singulis anablyphice sculpta, et a quodam Tiberio Claudio Faventino dicata...eademque imaginibus decorata, originem, ac primordia Urbis Romae a Paridis pomo ad lupam lactantem pueros, quasi ab ovo repraesentat...]
record.note: (Engraving n.4:unsigned)
This engraving, the second of three within the set, shows six scenes of the Trojan War; numbers 3 and 5, the companion plates, are not in our collection.

[Li cinque ordini con le loro regole et ornamenti cavati dall'antico]
record.engrv: [(Jerome David or Camillo Cungi)? after Giovanni Battista Montano]
record.note:
The following 29 engravings of the Libro primo
of Montano's Archit.
(see note to engravings B 354 to B 355) present definite variants from those included in the 1636 and 1691 editions (the 1624 edition has not been examined). The inscriptions and plate numbers listed in brackets are those of the 1636 and 1691 editions.
record.inscrip: [La colonna del presente ordine deve essere alta 7. diametri...]
record.note: (Engraving n.3)

record.inscrip: [Li cinque ordini con le loro regole et ornamenti cavati dall'antico]
record.engrv: [(Jerome David or Camillo Cungi)? after Giovanni Battista Montano]
record.note:
The following 29 engravings of the Libro primo
of Montano's Archit.
(see note to engravings B 354 to B 355) present definite variants from those included in the 1636 and 1691 editions (the 1624 edition has not been examined). The inscriptions and plate numbers listed in brackets are those of the 1636 and 1691 editions.
record.inscrip: Toscano. La luce di questo portico, o vero loggia e larga quattro diametri et alta 8...]
record.note: (Engraving n.5)

record.inscrip: [Li cinque ordini con le loro regole et ornamenti cavati dall'antico]
record.engrv: [(Jerome David or Camillo Cungi)? after Giovanni Battista Montano]

(see note to engravings B 354 to B 355) present definite variants from those included in the 1636 and 1691 editions (the 1624 edition has not been examined). The inscriptions and plate numbers listed in brackets are those of the 1636 and 1691 editions.
record.inscrip: [Qui si mostrano molte, e variate basi racolte da diversi fragmenti delli edifitii antichi...]
record.note: (Engraving n.6)
Number 33 at lower right.

record.inscrip: [Li cinque ordini con le loro regole et ornamenti cavati dall'antico]

record.inscrip: Dalli antichi fragmenti di capitelli potranno li studiosi formar nuovi pensieri...
record.note: (Engraving n.7)

record.inscrip: [Dorico. Essendo nel' presente foglio notato il tutto con numeri...]
record.note: (Engraving n.10)
Number 16 at lower right.

record.inscrip: [Di questa colonna...quale e senza base se ne vedano li vestigii nel Teatro di Marcello...]
record.note: (Engraving n.11)

record.inscrip: [Dorico. Da questo oltre l'altezza, et intercolunio, che si mostra, si potra anco pigliare la regola dello scompartimento delli trigliffi, e metope...]
record.note: (Engraving n.12)

record.inscrip: [Li cinque ordini con le loro regole et ornamenti cavati dall'antico]

record.inscrip: Sia divisa la grossezza della colonna dabasso in parte cinque...
record.note: (Engraving n.14)
Number 20 at lower right.

record.inscrip: [Li cinque ordini con le loro regole et ornamenti cavati dall'antico]

record.inscrip: [Dorico. L'architrave, fregio, e cornice e la quarta parte dell'altezza della sua colonna...]

record.inscrip: [Li cinque ordini con le loro regole et ornamenti cavati dall'antico]

record.note: (Engraving n.17)

record.inscrip: [Li cinque ordini con le loro regole et ornamenti cavati dall'antico]

record.inscrip:
[Fatta che sia la proportione dell'architrave, fregio e cornice sopra la 4 a
parte della sua colonna...]

[Il presente architrave, fregio e cornice, e la 4 a
. parte dell'altezza della sua colonna...]

record.inscrip: [Li cinque ordini con le loro regole et ornamenti cavati dall'antico]

record.inscrip: [Composito. In questo non solo si vedono le sue proportioni con le misure, e regole, ma anco il bello, e ricco modo, che havevano li antichi, nell'ornare i loro tempii e teatri]
record.note: (Engraving n.31)

record.inscrip: [Li cinque ordini con le loro regole et ornamenti cavati dall'antico]

record.inscrip: [Composito. Si mostra la varieta, che usavano gli antichi intorno alla proportione de membri delle cornice...]
record.note: (Engraving n.33)

record.inscrip: [Li cinque ordini con le loro regole et ornamenti cavati dall'antico]
record.engrv: [(Jerome David or Camillo Cungi)? after Giovanni Battista Montano]

record.inscrip: [Composito. Qui si vede, che gli antichi...non stavano soggetti alli ordini non facendo le foglie d'uguali parti in altezza, et anco il modo di fare il fregio curvato con diversi ornamenti...]
record.note: (Engraving n.34)

record.subj: Plan And Elevation Of An Ancient Temple
record.inscrip: [Questo tempio di ordine Corinthio fu fatto dalli antichi tra S. Bastiano, e la Cappella detta Domine Quo Vadis]
record.note:
This engraving, which appears in the second book of the de Rossi edition of Montano which contains the Scielta & varii tempietti antichi
, does not appear in the larger 66 plate editions published in 1624 and 1636 (BM v.163, col.66 lists a 1624 edition containing 59 plates; BN v.117, col.1075 lists copies of the 1624 edition containing 65 and 66 plates respectively). The 1638 edition of the Scielta
and the one published in 1708 have not been examined. For further bibliography cf. entries for engravings B 354 and B 355 and B356 and B 357. Cf. also G. Zander, "Le invenzioni architettoniche de Giovanni Battista Montano Milanese (1534-1621)" in Universita di Roma. Quaderni dell'Istituto di storia dell'architectura
, 30 (1958) and 49-50 (1962).

Each engraving contains three ornamental figures. According to L-A v.1, p.61 and Meyer, v.2, p.26, n.53, a series of twelve engravings containing 36 herms, caryatides, and pilasters was executed by Jacques Androuet du Cerceau.

Each engraving contains three ornamental figures. According to L-A v.1, p.61 and Meyer, v.2, p.26, n.53, a series of twelve engravings containing 36 herms, caryatides, and pilasters was executed by Jacques Androuet du Cerceau.
The letter S appears at lower part of engraving.

record.subj: Views Of Rome And Of Other Cities And Places
record.inscrip: Ruinarum varii prospectus ruriumque aliquot delineationes
record.engrv: Philippe and/or Theodore Galle after Henri Cleve
record.ref: BM v.40, col.386 s.v. Cleef (Henri van)
record.note:
H. van Cleve's signature and monogram appear on all 38 engravings with the exception of engraving n.22 of the set (C 554) which lacks the monogram. Philip Galle's signature also appears on all the engravings while that of his son Theodore appears on engraving n.1 (C 533) only. An earlier edition of the Ruinarum
, published by Ph. Galle ca.1587, is listed in A-B p.513, sub albo E 108. The sequence of the engravings in these two editions is not the same.
record.inscrip: Ruinarum varii...delineationes. Milvius pons
record.note: (Engraving n.1: title page)

Philip Galle's signature also appears on all the engravings while that of his son Theodore appears on engraving n.1 (C 533) only. An earlier edition of the Ruinarum
, published by Ph. Galle ca.1587, is listed in A-B p.513, sub albo E 108. The sequence of the engravings in these two editions is not the same.
record.inscrip: Colisei prospectus
record.note: (Engraving n.6)

record.note:
Probably part of the Operum antiquorum Romanorum hinc inde per diversas Europae regiones extructorum reliquias ac ruinas...
published by Hieronymus Cock in 1562 with either 21 engraved plates (Hol v.4, p.184, n.36-56) or with approximately 26 plates (BM v.41, col.10). The only dated engraving in the set listed here is C 590. Cock's signature appears on every engraving.

record.inscrip: Veue de l'Eglise Sainct Pierre, et du Chasteau Sainct Ange
[Les Eglises des Stations de Rome]
record.note: Probably part of a set of at least 12 engravings. According to A-B, engravings C 597 and C 599-601 bore numbers 15, 17, 16, and 13 respectively in an edition which they refer to as "Albo E 59", but which they fail to include in their bibliography (cf. p.514 of their catalogue). All four engravings have also a French and a Latin inscription.

record.inscrip: [Lascivie]
record.engrv: [Giovanni Jacopo Caraglio after Perino del Vaga and Rosso Rossi]
record.note:
Part of a set of either 15 (Ba, NaKL, Vienna) or 20 engravings (Huber, Bryan). None of the reference sources listed above mentions the ottave
which are part of the inscription. The collector's mark of Thomas Lawrence (1769-1830) appears on all three engravings (cf. Mon v.5, p.154, n.751).

record.ref: NaKL v.2, p.463, and v.3, p.4
record.note:
Engraving number 27 of a set of 30 plus an unnumbered title page published as Galeria nel Palazzo Farnese di Roma
in 1657; other editions are dated c.1700-1725 and, the one published by Monaldin, towards the end of the 18th century. This engraving is numbered 28 in the edition executed by Jacques Belly and published in 1641 as La Galerie du Palais Farnese
(cf. Weigert, v.1, p.347, n.28).

record.inscrip: [Ex antiquis cameorum et gemmae delineata. Liber secundus]
record.engrv: [Philippe Thomassin or anonymous after Aenea Vico or Philippe Thomassin?]
record.note:
Part of a set of 34 numbered engravings. The inscriptions added to these engravings do not appear in the 1618 edition of the Ex antiquis.
For Thomassin's companion volume, the liber primus
, a collection of engravings of Roman statues, cf. engravings C 903 to C 914.

record.inscrip: [Antiquarum statuarum urbis Romae (liber primus)]
record.note: (For other sources cf. individual entries below.) Part of a set of 52 numbered engravings plus a title page. The following plates are missing from the University's set of 48 engravings (not 49 as stated by Lowry, col.48a):.
1. Title page: see Ashby, p.116 for this plate..
2. Statue of Marcus Aurelius (pl.n.42): for copies of this engraving see Cav(P), pl.42 and Cav I-II, pl.68 (C 804)..
3. Statue of the Tiber (pl.n.43): see Cav(P), pl.43 and Cav I-II, pl.69 (C 805)..
4. Statue of Pasquino (pl.n.52): see Cav(P), pl.52 and Cav I-II, pl.92 (C 818)..
For a parallel set of 52 engravings, arranged in the same order as Cavalieri's, published ca.1560 at Nancy, and attributed to Pierre Woeiriot, cf. L-A v.2, p.165, n.18.
*See also general note *, p.
record.inscrip: Romae colossus celebris, in hortis Car Cesis cui Dacia subest
record.note: (B) Cav I-II, pl.19; Vac-van S, pl.36. In engraving A 90 of this collection, the arrangement of this statue plus the two following ones (C 706 and C 707) is shown on one plate.

record.inscrip: [Antiquarum statuarum urbis Romae (liber primus)]
record.note: For other sources cf. individual entries below.) Part of a set of 52 numbered engravings plus a title page. The following plates are missing from the University's set of 48 engravings (not 49 as stated by Lowry, col.48a):.
1. Title page: see Ashby, p.116 for this plate..
2. Statue of Marcus Aurelius (pl.n.42): for copies of this engraving see Cav(P), pl.42 and Cav I-II, pl.68 (C 804)..
3. Statue of the Tiber (pl.n.43): see Cav(P), pl.43 and Cav I-II, pl.69 (C 805)..

For a parallel set of 52 engravings, arranged in the same order as Cavalieri's, published ca.1560 at Nancy, and attributed to Pierre Woeiriot, cf. L-A v.2, p.165, n.18.
*See also general note *, p.

For a parallel set of 52 engravings, arranged in the same order as Cavalieri's, published ca.1560 at Nancy, and attributed to Pierre Woeiriot, cf. L-A v.2, p.165, n.18.
*See also general note *, p.

record.pub: [Andrea and Michelangelo della Vaccaria] (though signed by Lorenzo della Vaccaria) or [Goert van Schaych]

record.note: Part of a set of 80 engravings which were numbered for the first time in the 1621 van Schaych edition. The engravings included in our collection apparently come from an undetermined number of different Vaccaria-van Schaych editions. Missing in this set is plate number 30, a statue of Minerva copied from Cav I-II, pl.38 (C 768); two different proofs of numbers 45, 78, and 80 of the set are included in our collection.
* See also general note *, p.

record.ref: NaKL v.16, p.506, n.18 (attributes the whole set to Orazio de Santis and Cherubino Alberti)
Cf. also the references for engravings C 705 to C 752
record.note: Part of a set of 80 engravings which were numbered for the first time in the 1621 van Schaych edition. The engravings included in our collection apparently come from an undetermined number of different Vaccaria-van Schaych editions. Missing in this set is plate number 30, a statue of Minerva copied from Cav I-II, pl.38 (C 768); two different proofs of numbers 45, 78, and 80 of the set are included in our collection.
* See also general note *, p.
record.inscrip: Jovis in Capitolii fastigio statis marmores statua
record.note: Ashby, p.154, p1.n.11, affirms hat it was copied from Cav I-II, p1.76; comparison of these two plates, however, shows that they are only identical in subject.

record.pub: [Andrea and Michelangelo della Vaccaria] (though signed by Lorenzo della Vaccaria) or [Goert van Schaych]
record.ref: NaKL v.16, p.506, n.18 (attributes the whole set to Orazio de Santis and Cherubino Alberti)
Cf. also the references for engravings C 705 to C 752
record.note: Part of a set of 80 engravings which were numbered for the first time in the 1621 van Schaych edition. The engravings included in our collection apparently come from an undetermined number of different Vaccaria-van Schaych editions. Missing in this set is plate number 30, a statue of Minerva copied from Cav I-II, pl.38 (C 768); two different proofs of numbers 45, 78, and 80 of the set are included in our collection.
* See also general note *, p.
record.inscrip: Romae Colosus celebris cur Dacia capta sub est Romae in hortis Caesiis.
record.note: (A) Cav I-II, pl.19. (B) Cav I, pl.1 (C 705).

Missing in this set is plate number 30, a statue of Minerva copied from Cav I-II, pl.38 (C 768); two different proofs of numbers 45, 78, and 80 of the set are included in our collection.
* See also general note *, p.

All of these engravings are in reverse of the Vaccaria-van Schaych one. Cf. also the note to the following engraving.

record.inscrip: Antiquarum statuarum urbis Romae, quae in publicis privatisque locis visuntur icones
record.engrv: [Orazio de Santis, Cherubino Alberti et al. after Giovanni Battista Cavalieri et al.]
record.pub: [Andrea and Michelangelo della Vaccaria] (though signed by Lorenzo della Vaccaria) or [Goert van Schaych]
record.ref: NaKL v.16, p.506, n.18 (attributes the whole set to Orazio de Santis and Cherubino Alberti)
Cf. also the references for engravings C 705 to C 752
record.note: Part of a set of 80 engravings which were numbered for the first time in the 1621 van Schaych edition. The engravings included in our collection apparently come from an undetermined number of different Vaccaria-van Schaych editions. Missing in this set is plate number 30, a statue of Minerva copied from Cav I-II, pl.38 (C 768); two different proofs of numbers 45, 78, and 80 of the set are included in our collection.
* See also general note *, p.
record.inscrip: Alexandri Magni, vulgo Pasquinus eum socium detinens. Ante aedes Sermonaetis Card. Romani
record.note: This engraving is a duplicate of C 901; it lacks, however, the various legends and the Orsini arms (cf. Ashby, p.129, note 1 and Lowry, col.50b and note 29). The inscription of this statue in the Cavalieri editions, including the 1623 Marcucci one, locates it in front of the house of Cardinal Alfonso Caraffa (1540-1567), who was made a Cardinal on March 15, 1557 (cf. EC v.3, col.98a). In the inscription of the Vaccaria-van Schaych editions, this house had passed into the hands of a Cardinal of the Sermonetta branch which could mean any of the following members of the Caetani family who in hereditary succession were created Cardinals: Nicolo in 1538; Enrico in 1589; Bonfacio II in 1606; Antonio II in 1621; and Luigi (d.1642), the last Cardinal of that family, in 1626 (cf. EI v.8, p.252). The engraving of this statue executed by Jacques Granthomme ca.1597 is without an inscription but bears on the pedestal what appears to be the Caraffa arms.

record.inscrip: [Antiquarum statuarum urbis Romae liber primus]
record.ref: Thom. Cf. also the references listed for engravings C 705 to C 752
record.note: Part of a set of 50 unnumbered engravings including a title page. In the Thom-de Rossi edition, the plates are numbered from 1 through 50, and are followed by two unnumbered plates of larger dimensions than the numbered ones; they represent, respectively, the "Farnese Bull" (for which cf. Vaccaria-van Schaych, pl.21=C 841 in our collection, though with variants in the text of the inscription), and the "Laocoon" (cf. Vaccaria-van Schaych, pl.48=C 868 in our collection). The engraving numbers supplied in brackets in the entries listed below correspond to those of the Thom-de Rossi edition.
* See also general note *, p.

record.subj: Statues Of Famous Women Of Roman Antiquity
record.note: Possibly a complete set of six numbered engravings. It may be related to either the entry listed in Hol v.7, p.86, n.390-95 (engraved by Theodore Galle) and/or to the one listed on p.44 of the same volume, n.14-19, engraved by Pieter Jalhea Furnius (Dufour); both sets were engraved after J. Stradanus (van Straet). Furnius' set was published by Hieronymus Cock in 1573. Plate n.1 of our set (C 968) is signed by Philip Galle; the others are unsigned.

record.subj: Michelangelo's Christ In Santa Maria Sopra Minerva
record.engrv: Joan Biskop (Johannes Episcopius) (monogram) after Jacob Matham
record.note: Plate number 16 of a set of 57 numbered engravings plus an unnumbered title page. The two editions of the Paradigmata listed in NaKL v.1, p.531; T-B v.10, p.581; and Hol v.2, p.44, which mention 102 and 113 plates for these two editions, seem to be inaccurately described; the entry in BM does not indicate number of plates. Plate number 16 of the Paradigmata can also be found added as an appendix (with 25 other plates of the Paradigmata) to the edition of the Icones which was bound with the Ars pictoria of Alexander Browne (London, 1675). For an engraving of this same subject executed by N. Beatrizet cf. L-A v.1, p.78 and Goldscheider, pl.VIIg plus the note on p.207.

record.inscrip: [Signorum veterum icones]
record.note: Part of a set of 100 numbered plates plus an unnumbered title page. For the edition of the Icones included in the Paradigmata cf. the note to engraving C 976; the Icones bound with Perrier's Segmenta occurs only in the Rome, 1638 edition and not in the Rome-Paris, 1638 edition (cf. BM v.187, cols. 193-94 s.v. Perrier). The copy bound with Browne's Ars pictoria is the only one which possesses a half-title page, which reads Signorum icones semi-centuria altera, as well as a table of contents and two dedicatory letters; in this latter edition, however, most of the plates of the Icones do not bear Biskop's monogram.
record.inscrip: [Leda in villa Burghesia Pinciana adspectu triplici]
record.note: The inscription extends to the next two engravings in the set (C 978 and C 979).

Part of a set of numbered engravings which seems to represent a much abbreviated German version of or after Biskop's Icones. The engravings in the German edition are reversed. The Latin inscription for engraving C 985 was taken from the Icones edition bound with Browne's Ars pictoria. See also the notes to engravings C 976 and C 977 to C 981.

record.inscrip: Sibylla oder Sabina der Herrn Medices

record.subj: Statue Of A Priest And Priestess Of Isis (?)
Tomb Of M. Aur. F. Secundinus
record.inscrip: In palatio Cardinalis Medichini Tybure Romam adportatum
record.note: This is plate number 97 in a set of 96 plates numbered from 53 to 149 (number 125 is always missing). They are from part 4 of Boissard's Topographia (cf. Brunet, v.1, col.1069; L-A v.2, p.244, n.8). This fourth part still bears the 1598 publication date although it is from the second edition published at Frankfort in 1627. No later editions of part 4 are recorded.

record.inscrip: Novissima et acuratissima delineatio Romae veteris et novae, in viatorem usum et commoditatem
record.ref: Frutaz, v.1, pp.221-22, 224 and v.3, pianta 158, tav.357-63 and pianta 161, tav.377.

Graevius, Thes.
, v.4, pl. following Praefatio

record.inscrip: Quemadmodum magna tes illi Romani Imperatores de aliqua provincia regione populisve excissis et debellatis ac de regibus victis et captis Romae teiumpharunt
record.note: This engraving consists of two sheets which were glued together. Its subject matter is identical with that represented in engravings B 336 to B 346 of our collection, and in an engraving which faces cols.1347-48 in Graevius, Thes., v.9.

record.inscrip: Vera antiqui Capitolio descriptio
record.note: This engraving consists of three numbered sheets which were glued together. The name of Antonio Salamanca, who apparently had published them at an earlier date separately (he is listed in Qu as engraver), and the inscription Vera antiqui Capitolio descriptio have been scraped away from plates 1 and 3.
